channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tehran Journal: A Burger Joint That’s Iran’s Answer to McDonald’s
item.description: “We’re trying to get as close as we can to the McDonald’s experience,” says the owner of Mash Donald’s, one of an increasing number of Iranian knockoffs of American food culture.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Mash Donald's in Tehran, almost everything resembles its American counterpart — everything except the food.

item.title: Canadian Prime Minister Calls Federal Election
item.description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper broke with Canadian political tradition by formally opening the campaign in the middle of summer during what is a holiday weekend in most of the country.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Suicide Attack by Kurdish Militants in Turkey Kills 2 Soldiers
item.description: Twenty-four others were wounded after Kurdish militants rammed a tractor loaded with explosives into a military police station in eastern Turkey, the local authorities said.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Obama to Unveil Tougher Climate Plan With His Legacy in Mind
item.description: President Obama will unveil on Monday a set of environmental regulations devised to sharply cut planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions from the nation’s power plants and ultimately transform America’s electricity industry.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: If rules survive legal challenges, they could help shut down coal-fired plants like the Ghent Generating Station in Kentucky.

item.title: Censure and Clashes After West Bank Attack
item.description: Palestinians clashed with Israeli forces while thousands of Israelis flocked to rallies, all of them protesting a firebombing that killed a Palestinian toddler.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Laith al-Khaldi who was shot of Friday during a demonstration near Ramallah, died on Saturday.

item.title: Laos, Destination in Illegal Ivory Trade, So Far Eludes Global Crackdown
item.description: International efforts to curb illegal trade are not impacting Laos, where criminal gangs are said to take advantage of the weak rule of law and officials are thought to profit from trafficking.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: At a news conference in Bangkok in July, Thai customs officers displayed African elephant tusks that had been confiscated.

item.title: After Deal, Europeans Are Eager to Do Business in Iran
item.description: The rush to restart trade with Iran could make it more complicated to renew sanctions if the nuclear deal brokered by the United States falls apart.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Iran has a large middle class with educated women who want high-quality European brands, a French appliance executive says.

item.title: Aja Zanova, Top Czech Skater Who Defected to West, Dies at 84
item.description: Zanova was a world champion figure skater whose defection from Czechoslovakia as a teenager in 1950 made headlines around the world.
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Aja Zanova, in Switzerland in 1950. She is credited with being the first woman to land a double lutz in competition.

item.title: Taliban’s New Leader Urges Unity, Playing Down Peace Talk
item.description: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour declared that “jihad would continue” in Afghanistan in an audio recording released Saturday, though his message contained signs of hope for the Afghan government and Western diplomats.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Men in Pakistan read the Quran during prayers for Mullah Omar, whose death was confirmed by the Taliban this week.

item.title: Palm Oil Company Is Accused of Exploiting Liberia’s Ebola Crisis
item.description: During the height of the Ebola outbreak, a community signed over large swaths of farming land. Now, some are questioning the benefits, and ethics, of the deal.
item.dc:creator: CLAIR MacDOUGALL
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Wloh in his garden in Kabada. He said he was saddened by the decision to turn over farmland to palm oil production.

item.title: Flooding Spurs Disaster Zones in Myanmar
item.description: President Thein Sein declared four regions in western and central Myanmar as disaster zones as the government continued to face criticism for its slow response to floods and landslides across the country.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE

item.title: Plane Crash Kills Relatives of Bin Laden
item.description: Family members of the former Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden were among four people killed in a private jet crash in southern England, a Saudi ambassador said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 120 Degrees and No Relief? ISIS Takes Back Seat for Iraqis
item.description: One of the country’s largest recent grass-roots protests shut down traffic in Baghdad on Friday night, and more protests took place Saturday in southern Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Protesters in Baghdad on Friday. High temperatures have made the lack of reliable electricity a bigger political issue than usual.

item.title: Mark Karpeles, Chief of Bankrupt Bitcoin Exchange, Is Arrested in Tokyo
item.description: The police said they believed Mr. Karpeles had manipulated transaction records on a computer system that Mt. Gox used to swap Bitcoins for dollars.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Tibetan Who Called for Dalai Lama’s Return Is Said to Be Freed From Chinese Prison
item.description: Runggye Adak was jailed for eight years after calling for the spiritual leader’s return to Tibet in a speech at a major festival.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: New Meningitis Strain in Africa Brings Call for More Vaccines
item.description: An international consortium is seeking five million doses of the vaccine against Type C meningitis and says they must arrive by January to be effective.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Somali mothers waiting in line in Mogadishu to have their babies vaccinated against meningitis and other diseases in 2013. Meningitis C infections are on the rise across Africa.

item.title: World Briefing: Food Program Gets Emergency Cash
item.description: The anti-hunger agency of the United Nations said that it had averted a suspension of aid to 440,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan after the United States gave $65 million.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Lawmakers on Azerbaijan Trip Cleared
item.description: The House Ethics Committee announced that it had cleared 10 lawmakers and 32 House employees of any wrongdoing associated with a trip to Azerbaijan.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LIPTON

item.title: Rivals of ISIS Attack U.S.-Backed Syrian Rebel Group
item.description: The members trained by the United States to take on the Islamic State found themselves fighting off an attack from another Islamist faction.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: U.S. Decides to Retaliate Against China’s Hacking
item.description: The Obama administration decided a response was needed after the Chinese stole data on 20 million Americans from the Office of Personnel Management.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
